{{Infobox military person |name = Sir James Bremer |image = Sir James Bremer.jpg |image_size = 275 |caption = |birth_date = 26 September 1786 |birth_place = [[Portsea, Hampshire|Portsea]], Hampshire, England |death_date = 14 February 1850 (aged 63) |death_place = [[Tunbridge Wells]], Kent, England |placeofburial_label = |placeofburial = |placeofburial_coordinates = |allegiance = {{flagcountry|United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland}} |branch = {{navy|UK}} |serviceyears = 1802–1850 |rank = [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Rear-Admiral of the Blue]] |servicenumber = |unit = |commands = [[East Indies and China Station]] |battles_label = Wars |battles = [[Napoleonic Wars]]
[[First Anglo-Burmese War]]
[[First Opium War|First Anglo-Chinese War]] |awards = [[Order of the Bath|CB]] (1815)

[[Order of the Bath|KCB]] (1841)
[[China War Medal (1842)|China War Medal]] (1842) |relations = |laterwork = |signature = James Bremer signature.jpg |signature_size = 125 }} '''Sir James John Gordon Bremer''', [[Order of the Bath|KCB]], [[Royal Guelphic Order|KCH]] (26 September 1786 – 14 February 1850) was a British [[Royal Navy]] officer. He served in the [[Napoleonic Wars]], [[First Anglo-Burmese War]], and [[First Opium War|First Anglo-Chinese War]]. In China, he served twice as commander-in-chief of British forces. Born in [[Portsea, Portsmouth]], Bremer joined the [[Royal Naval Academy|Royal Naval College]] as a student in 1797. While serving in the [[East Indies]], he became commander of [[HMS Rattlesnake (1791)|HMS ''Rattlesnake'']] in 1807. He was promoted to captain in 1814 and was nominated a [[Order of the Bath|CB]] the following year. After becoming commander of [[HMS Tamar (1814)|HMS ''Tamar'']], he was sent to [[Melville Island (Northern Territory)|Melville Island]], Australia, in 1824 to establish a colony. Under his leadership, the north coast of Australia from 129° to 135° longitude was claimed as British territory. Bremer served twice as commander-in-chief of British forces in the First Anglo-Chinese War from 1839 to 1841. During the war, he took formal possession of [[Hong Kong Island]] for the United Kingdom in 1841. He was made a KCB the same year. In 1846, he was appointed second-in-command of the [[Channel Fleet]] and was superintendent of [[Woolwich Dockyard]] from which he retired in 1848. He died in 1850, having risen to the rank of rear-admiral. == Early career == Bremer was born on 26 September 1786 in [[Portsea, Hampshire|Portsea]], Hampshire, England.Laughton, J. K.. "Bremer, Sir James John Gordon (1786–1850)". ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'' (2004 ed.). Oxford University Press. {{doi|10.1093/ref:odnb/3313}}. He was the only son of [[Royal Navy]] Lieutenant James Bremer (who went missing in the [[East Indiaman]] ''Halswell'' off the coast of [[Dorset]], England, on 6 January 1786) and his wife Ann, daughter of Captain James Norman. In 1794, he joined the Royal Navy as a first-class volunteer on board the [[flagship]] of [[HMS Sandwich (1759)|HMS ''Sandwich'']] at the [[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore|Nore]] of Rear-Admiral [[Skeffington Lutwidge]], from which he was discharged in June 1795. On 8 October 1797, he became a student of the [[Royal Naval Academy|Royal Naval College]] in [[Portsmouth]], and re-embarked on 2 April 1802 as a midshipman on board [[HMS Endymion (1797)|HMS ''Endymion'']] of Captain [[Philip Charles Durham|Philip Durham]]. Until July 1805, Bremer served in the flagship of [[HMS Isis (1774)|HMS ''Isis'']] under Vice-Admiral [[James Gambier, 1st Baron Gambier|James Gambier]] and Rear-Admiral [[Edward Thornbrough]], on the [[Newfoundland Colony|Newfoundland]] and [[North Sea]] stations. Shortly after passing his examination, he was appointed sub-lieutenant of the [[gun-brig]] [[HMS Rapid (1804)|HMS ''Rapid'']]. On 3 August 1805, he became a lieutenant on board [[HMS Captain (1787)|HMS ''Captain'']] as part of [[William Cornwallis]]' force in pursuing a French fleet in [[Brest, France|Brest]], France.{{cite wikisource | class = dictionary | first = William Richard | last = O'Byrne | chapter = Bremer, James John Gordon | wslink = A Naval Biographical Dictionary | title = A Naval Biographical Dictionary | year = 1849 | publisher = [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray]] }} On 9 May 1806, Bremer was appointed to [[HMS Diana (1794)|HMS ''Diana'']] of Captain [[Thomas James Maling]] in the [[Mediterranean Fleet (United Kingdom)|Mediterranean Station]], from where he proceeded to the [[Davis Strait]]. On 6 October, he served on board [[HMS Imogen (1805)|HMS ''Imogen'']] of Captain [[Thomas Garth (Royal Navy)|Thomas Garth]] in the Mediterranean. On 28 May 1807, he was appointed to the ''[[French frigate Psyché (1804)|Psyché]]'' of Captain William Wooldridge in the [[East Indies]], where he became commander of [[HMS Rattlesnake (1791)|HMS ''Rattlesnake'']] on 13 October. He became a captain on 7 June 1814.Stephen, Leslie (1886). ''[https://archive.org/stream/dictionaryofnati06stepuoft#page/256/mode/2up Dictionary of National Biography]''. Volume 6. New York: Macmillan and Co. pp. 256–257. On 4 June 1815, he was nominated a Companion of the Most Honourable Military [[Order of the Bath]] (CB). == Australia == On 18 September 1823, Bremer was appointed commander of [[HMS Tamar (1814)|HMS ''Tamar'']]. In February 1824, he was sent to [[Melville Island (Northern Territory)|Melville Island]], Australia, to establish a colony. The site was intended as a military settlement to secure British trade in the region. It was hoped that a market would open to British merchants in the [[Malay Archipelago]].Scott, Ernest (1988). ''Australia - Cambridge History of the British Empire''. Volume 7 (Part 1). Cambridge University Press. pp. 129–130. ISBN 0-521-35621-0. In June 1824, Bremer arrived in [[Sydney]] where he spent a month collecting troops and stores.Bach, J (1966). "[http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A010137b.htm Bremer, Sir James John Gordon (1786 - 1850)]". ''Australian Dictionary of Biography''. Retrieved 7 June 2011. On 24 August 1824, he left [[Port Jackson]], Sydney,"[http://www.smh.com.au/travel/travel-factsheet/melville-island--culture-and-history-20081125-6gpm.html Melville Island - Culture and History]". ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' (25 November 2008). Retrieved 7 June 2011. on board the ''Tamar'', accompanied by the ''[[Countess of Harcourt (1812 ship)|Countess of Harcourt]]'' and the ''Lady Nelson''.Satham, Pamela (1989). ''The Origin of Australia's Capital Cities''. Cambridge University Press. p. 276. ISBN 0-521-40832-6. The ships transported [[Royal Marines]] and 44 convicts guarded by the [[Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment)|3rd Regiment]]. After sailing through the [[Torres Strait]], he arrived in [[Port Essington]] on 20 September. The north coast of Australia from 129° to 135° longitude was declared British territory. Bremer rejected Port Essington as a settlement due to its lack of fresh drinking water. On 26 September, the party landed at King Cove in Melville Island to build a settlement, which was named [[Fort Dundas]] on 21 October. However, the site was unhealthy, expensive to maintain, and did not develop into an advantageous commercial trading post. In November 1828, orders were given to abandon the post. In November 1824, Bremer sailed for India where he served in the [[First Anglo-Burmese War]]. On 25 January 1836, he was made a Knight Commander of the [[Royal Hanoverian Guelphic Order]] (KCH). In 1837, Port Essington was again selected as a possible trading station by [[Charles Grant, 1st Baron Glenelg|Baron Glenelg]]. Bremer, who commanded the ''[[HMS Alligator (1821)|Alligator]]'' and ''[[HMS Britomart (1820)|Britomart]]'', was again given charge of the expedition. He established a new post in October 1838, calling it Port Victoria. The port was active until 1843 and by 1849, Port Essington was abandoned after it had no commercial or military value. Under the encouragement of New South Wales Governor [[George Gipps]], Bremer left Port Essington for China in June 1839, with the ships under his command, after news of trouble in the Chinese city of [[Guangzhou|Canton]]. == China == [[File:Chusan conference 1840.jpg|thumb|250px|Bremer (left of centre) requesting Chinese officials aboard [[HMS Wellesley (1815)|HMS ''Wellesley'']] to surrender Chusan a day before the [[Capture of Chusan|British captured]] the island]] Rear-Admiral [[Frederick Lewis Maitland (Royal Navy officer)|Frederick Maitland]], commander of the [[East Indies and China Station]], died in November 1839. As the senior naval officer, Bremer took over as commander-in-chief of British forces in the [[First Opium War|First Anglo-Chinese War]] as [[Commodore (Royal Navy)|commodore]].Ouchterlony, John (1844). ''[https://archive.org/stream/chinesewaraccoun00ouchrich#page/40 The Chinese War]''. London: Saunders and Otley. pp. 37–38. He was replaced by Rear-Admiral [[George Elliot (1784–1863)|George Elliot]] in July 1840, but after Elliot's return home in November 1840, Bremer again assumed the post until the arrival of Sir [[Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Shenstone|William Parker]] in August 1841.Urban, Sylvanus (1850). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=OKvPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA535 The Gentleman's Magazine]'' (1850). Volume 188. London: John Bowyer Nichols and Son. p. 535. Bremer commanded the [[capture of Chusan]] (5–6 July 1840),''The London Gazette'': [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/19930/pages/2991 no. 19930. p. 2991]. 15 December 1840. [[Second Battle of Chuenpi]] (7 January 1841),''The London Gazette'': [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/19976/pages/1162 no. 19976. p. 1162]. 7 May 1841. [[Battle of the Bogue]] (23–26 February),''The London Gazette'': [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/19984/pages/1426 no. 19984. p. 1426]. 3 June 1841. [[Battle of First Bar]] (27 February),''The London Gazette'': [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/19987/pages/1502 no. 19987. p. 1502]. 11 June 1841. [[Battle of Whampoa]] (2 March), and [[Battle of Canton (March 1841)|Battle of Canton]] (18 March).''The London Gazette'': [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/19987/pages/1503 no. 19987. p. 1503]. 11 June 1841. After Plenipotentiary [[Charles Elliot]] declared the cession of [[Hong Kong Island]] to the United Kingdom on 20 January 1841,''[https://books.google.com/books?id=FC8MAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA63 The Chinese Repository]'' (1841). Volume 10. pp. 63–64. Bremer reported on 26 January that he "proceeded to Hong Kong, and took formal possession of the island in Her Majesty's name, and hoisted the colours on it, with the usual salutes and ceremonies."''The London Gazette'': p. [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/19984/pages/1424 1424]. 3 June 1841. Issue 19984. This area became known as [[Possession Point]].Tsang, Steve (2004). ''A Modern History of Hong Kong''. London: I. B. Tauris. p. 16. ISBN 1-84511-419-1. On 1 February, he issued a joint proclamation with Elliot to the inhabitants, declaring the island British territory. On 24 August, he left China aboard the ''Atlanta'' with Elliot.[[Robert Montgomery Martin|Martin, Robert Montgomery]] (1841). "[https://books.google.com/books?id=IGw5AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA488 Colonial Intelligence]". ''The Colonial Magazine and Commercial-Maritime Journal''. Volume 6. London: Fisher, Son, & Co. p. 488. For his services, Bremer received a vote of thanks from both houses of parliament, and on 29 July, he was made a Knight Commander of the Most Honourable Military [[Order of the Bath]] (KCB). == Later career == On 30 April 1846, under Admiral [[Francis Augustus Collier]], Bremer was appointed second-in-command of the [[Channel Fleet]], with his [[broad pennant]] on board [[HMS Queen (1839)|HMS ''Queen'']]. On 24 November, he became superintendent of the [[Woolwich Dockyard]], where he commanded the yacht ''[[HMS William and Mary|William and Mary]]''. He retired from the dockyard on 13 November 1848. On 15 September 1849, Bremer was appointed to [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Rear-Admiral of the Blue]].''The London Gazette'': [https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/21021/page/2883 no. 21021 p. 2883]. 21 September 1849.Burke, J. Bernard (1850). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=YDEuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA553 St. James's Magazine, and Heraldic and Historical Register]''. Volume 2. London: E. Churton. pp. 41–42. He served as a magistrate in [[Devon]]shire. He died of [[diabetes mellitus]] on 14 February 1850 at [[Tunbridge Wells]], Kent, England. == Family == On 27 March 1811, Bremer married Harriet, daughter of Royal Marines officer Thomas Wheeler and widow of Reverend [[George Glasse]]. They had two sons and four daughters:Burke, J. Bernard (1852). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=9mNHAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA138 A Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Landed Gentry of Great Britain & Ireland, for 1852]''. Volume 1. London: Colburn and Co. p. 138. *Emma Margaret (c. 1815 – 19 July 1877"[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/13400256 Deaths]". ''The Sydney Morning Herald''. 21 September 1877. p. 8.); married Royal Navy officer [[Augustus Leopold Kuper|Augustus Kuper]] on 20 June 1837 *Isabel Harriet Ann (c. 1816 – 13 April 1866Urban, Sylvanus (1866). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=X_dfAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA770 The Gentleman's Magazine and Historical Review]''. Volume 1. London: Bradbury, Evans, & Co. p. 770.); married British Army officer Henry Sabine Browne on 26 February 1840 *Emily (c. 1817 – 21 December 1869"[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/13190909 Deaths]". ''The Sydney Morning Herald''. 26 February 1868. p. 8.); married Alfred Howard on 5 April 1838 *Ellen Susan (born c. 1818); married British Army officer Collingwood Fenwick at Plymouth on 15 October 1844Urban, Sylvanus (1844). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=k2YdAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA644 The Gentleman's Magazine]''. Volume 22. London: John Bowyer Nichols and Son. p. 644. *Edward Gordon (18 September 1819 – 7 April 1847Burke, John (1847). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Cfg8AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA501 The Patrician]''. Volume 3. London: E. Churton. p. 501.); Royal Navy officer *John de Courcy (17 February 1822 – 6 January 1891 in [[Rose Bay, New South Wales|Rose Bay]], Sydney, Australia"[http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13790421 Deaths]". ''The Sydney Morning Herald''. 8 January 1891. p. 1.) After Harriet's death in 1846, Bremer married Jemima Mary Harriet (1801–1879), the eldest daughter of Royal Navy officer [[James Brisbane]], on 8 February 1848 at [[Tunbridge Wells]].''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8kMFAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA200 Tait's Edinburgh Magazine, for 1850]'' (1850). Volume 17. Edinburgh: Sutherland and Knox. p. 200.''[https://books.google.com/books?id=HhwkAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA186 The Annual Register, or a View of the History and Politics of the Year 1848]''. Volume 90. London: George Woodfall and Son. p. 186. == Namesakes == *[[Bremer River (Queensland)|Bremer River]], Queensland, Australia; named by explorer [[John Oxley]] in 1828{{cite web |url=http://www.theage.com.au/travel/travel-factsheet/ipswich--culture-and-history-20081120-6cob.html |title=Ipswich - Culture and History |author= |date= |work= |publisher=theage.com.au |accessdate=8 December 2009}} *[[Bremer River (South Australia)|Bremer River]], South Australia; originally the Hindmarsh River, renamed the Bremer River in 1839 *[[Bremer Bay, Western Australia|Bremer Bay]], Western Australia; named by [[John Septimus Roe]], who served under Bremer on board the ''Tamar'' from 1824 to 1827{{LandInfo WA|c|B|2007-05-30}} *[[Bremer Range]] and its highest peak, Mount Gordon, Western Australia; named by Roe in 1848–49Hopper, S.D.; Nicolle, D. (2007). "[http://www.dec.wa.gov.au/images/stories/nature/science/nuytsia/17/1/185-194.pdf Diamond gum (Eucalyptus rhomboidea: Myrtaceae), a new threatened species endemic to the Bremer Range of the Southwest Australian Floristic Region]". ''Nuytsia'' '''17''': 185. {{ISSN|0085-4417}}. Retrieved 6 June 2011. *[[Bremer Island]], Northern Territory, Australia"[http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/2344240 N.T. Island to Be Re-named]". ''The Canberra Times'' '''8''' (2045). 31 March 1934. p. 2. Retrieved 6 June 2011. *[[Bremer Hill]], Hong Kong Island == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category|James Bremer}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box | title=[[East Indies and China Station|Commander-in-Chief, East Indies and China Station]] | years=January 1840 – July 1840 | before=[[Frederick Lewis Maitland (Royal Navy rear-admiral)|Sir Frederick Maitland]] | after=[[George Elliot (1784–1863)|Sir George Elliot]]}} |- {{succession box | title=[[East Indies and China Station|Commander-in-Chief, East Indies and China Station]] | years=November 1840 – August 1841 | before=[[George Elliot (1784–1863)|Sir George Elliot]] | after=[[Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Shenstone|Sir William Parker]]}} {{end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bremer, James}} [[Category:1786 births]] [[Category:1850 deaths]] [[Category:British military personnel of the First Anglo-Burmese War]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Royal Guelphic Order]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the First Opium War]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the French Revolutionary Wars]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the Napoleonic Wars]]
